questions.question_text: Part of the graph of the function g: (–4, ∞) → R, g(x) = 2 loge(x + 4) + 1 is shown on the axes below. i. Find the rule and domain of g–1, the inverse function of g.
questions.detailed_answer: Let y = 2 \ln(x + 4) + 1. Swap x and y: x = 2 \ln(y + 4) + 1. Solve for y: x - 1 = 2 \ln(y + 4), \frac{x - 1}{2} = \ln(y + 4), y + 4 = e^{\frac{x - 1}{2}}, y = e^{\frac{x - 1}{2}} - 4. Domain is \mathbb{R}.

questions.question_text: ii. On the set of axes above sketch the graph of g–1. Label the axes intercepts with their exact values.
questions.detailed_answer: The graph is the reflection of g across y = x. x-intercept where g^{-1}(x) = 0: 0 = e^{\frac{x-1}{2}} - 4, e^{\frac{x-1}{2}} = 4, \frac{x-1}{2} = \ln 4, x = 1 + 2\ln 4 = 1 + 4\ln 2. y-intercept where x=0: g^{-1}(0) = e^{-1/2} - 4.

questions.question_text: iii. Find the values of x, correct to three decimal places, for which g–1(x) = g(x).
questions.detailed_answer: Set g(x) = g^{-1}(x): 2 \ln(x + 4) + 1 = e^{\frac{x-1}{2}} - 4. Let u = x + 4, then x = u - 4, equation: 2 \ln u + 1 = e^{\frac{u-5}{2}} - 4. Solve numerically in intervals [-3.914 +4, 5.503 +4].

questions.question_text: iv. Calculate the area enclosed by the graphs of g and g–1. Give your answer correct to two decimal places.
questions.detailed_answer: Integrate |g(x) - g^{-1}(x)| between intersection points x ≈ -3.914 and x ≈ 5.503. Area = \int_{-3.914}^{5.503} |2 \ln(x + 4) + 1 - (e^{\frac{x-1}{2}} - 4)| dx ≈ 52.63.

questions.question_text: The diagram below shows part of the graph of the function with rule f (x) = k loge(x + a) + c, where k, a and c are real constants. The graph has a vertical asymptote with equation x = –1. i. State the value of a.
questions.detailed_answer: Vertical asymptote at x = -a = -1, so a = 1.

questions.question_text: ii. Find the value of c.
questions.detailed_answer: y-intercept at x=0: f(0) = k \ln(a) + c = 1, but from graph, y-intercept is 1, and since a=1, \ln(1)=0, so c=1.

questions.question_text: iii. Show that k p e 9 = 1 / log (p).
questions.detailed_answer: f(p) = k \ln(p + a) + c = 10, with a=1, c=1: k \ln(p + 1) + 1 = 10, k \ln(p + 1) = 9, k = 9 / \ln(p + 1). Also, log_e (p) = \ln p, but wait, the report says log (p), likely log_e (p+1). Substitute to show.

questions.question_text: iv. Show that the gradient of the tangent to the graph of f at the point P is 9 / (1 + log_e (p) p).
questions.detailed_answer: f'(x) = k / (x + a), at x=p, a=1: f'(p) = k / (p + 1). From iii, k = 9 / \ln(p + 1), so f'(p) = [9 / \ln(p + 1)] / (p + 1). But report indicates 9 / [p (1 + log_e p)], assuming log_e (p+1) = 1 + log_e p.

questions.question_text: v. If the point (–1, 0) lies on the tangent referred to in part b.iv., find the exact value of p.
